comments.commentBody: You seem to like the man, why not his message, no need to elevate him by defaming a large block of Americans. He certainly was not the worst president, nor does it matter. His term was benign compared to democrats who followed. I think Iran will miss him. Unconditional forgiveness is something they need but don't deserve.

I know it's become almost a GOP throwaway line about Carter being the "worst" president, but it still infuriates me. He had faults and lots of them, and he readily admits it. But he brokered an historic peace deal. Another president also did something historic -- he started an unnecessary war. And he's never readily admitted ANY mistakes. So enough already with the twisted revisionist history.

I looked at my computer screen today and watched a powerful profile in courage being exhibited with humility and grace beyond the reach, or even comprehension, of most of us in our lives.

Part of the pathway to President Carter's great humanitarian work as ex-president was laid down not only by his Christian faith, but also by Mr. Carter's neighbors, Millard and Linda Fuller, who were residents of the Christian farming effort in southern Georgia called Koinonia, which in turn led to the founding of Habitat for Humanity by the Fullers, which became a model of action for the ex-president. This shows how the good works of some can spread to others and lead to great accomplishment when in the right hands.

President Carter's life is also a reminder to me personally, as it should be to all of us, that good intentions without strong actions are essentially nothing. If we believe we can make a better world and act on it strongly, consistently and intently, it will be realized. I thank President Carter for his life and his example.

Like George McGovern and Dwight Eisenhower, Jimmy Carter was a military veteran of the type that the World War II draft dodger John Wayne played acting in the movies. No one hates and knows war more than a warrior.
I couldn't agree more, I find him so inspirational...

I was born in 1951. Jimmy Carter was/is the best president we've had in my lifetime.

I'm heartened to see all the wonderful comments listed for this great man.

A graduate of Annapolis, degreed Engineer from the great institution, respectful of the future and the present implications for the future. Jimmy Carter was, as POTUS, arguably the last best hope for this nation because he tried to warn and motivate the nation to act, on our collective energy future.

If we could only follow his example, to live our lives always with compassion and love. To do what we can--in small ways and large--to make our world a better place. Then we too could be "at ease."

Thank you for your work, Mr. and Mrs. Carter, for your brave spirits, and for your example.

There are some men who are too decent and good to be President of the United States of America.  I've always felt President Carter belongs in that category.  And I say that with the greatest respect and admiration, especially considering the work he has accomplished since he left office.  One wonders how many lives he has impacted for good since leaving office compared to presidents who serve two terms impact during those 8 small, contentious, cartoonish years.
Thank you for not having amnesia over Carter's presidency.  He was right up there with Nixon.  However, Carter became great after his presidency.

Jimmy Carter may not have been the greatest president of our time, but he certainly is the most humanitarian. In fact, his humanitarian impulses often seemed to get in the way of his being the "best" of presidents. At least that is how I see it.

I always thought that Jimmy Carter is a great man and the countless comments have proved my belief. What a graceful statement he has given, hats off to him. I wish and pray that this gentleman should continue to fight the dreaded disease with his evergreen smile and should overcome it come what may.

If only all 320,392 candidates running for President of the United States (as of today) would listen and read and learn from this man.

I can dream, can't I?

@Alicia Kennelly
Your question implies that, for prisoners, the American jurisprudence system is seen as illegitimate as Holocaust inmates knew the Nazi state and its jurisprudence to be. The source of hope for concentration camp inmates was in knowing they were victims of an illegitimate process that was only a decade old, and also involved in a death-struggle with opposing nation-states. Freedom was only a matter of time, and whether one would survive long enough.

Contrast that with the typical inmate in the American prison system. The entire process is widely considered 'legitimate' and supremely stable in its longevity. If you are found guilty and serving a life-sentence without chance of parole in the US, there's precious little hope to think those terms will ever be changed in your lifetime.
While I applaud the accomplishment of these two women, many high ranking officers do not have the Ranger tab.  It's hardly necessary for promotion, especially if you are not in combat arms.

Just a few items to highlight how ridiculous this has been up to now:
As recently as 1991: 5 female airmen who "dared" to do full push-ups during group PT (rather than half ones) in basic training were actually disciplined, and FORCED to do the lesser exercise while staring into the eyes of their male counterparts doing the full load, even as they had already demonstrated capacity and a willingness lead by example. In 1992, we had a running [intramural-type] squadron team of 8 women who all would have scored over 85, 5 of whom would have scored over 95 on the MEN's scale --- including the upper body strength components. But the raw scores demonstrating this were not recorded -- not even as "additional comments" in an EPR. Not even after asking permission for the sake of accuracy.
Only the fact that they aced the (very sadly inadequate) women's requirements was documented; so the only data recorded for years would NEVER show that women could do much more.

Imagine having to look your brother flight in the eye while they're ordered to carry their full weight while you're ordered to carry less than half of yours -- could there possibly have been a better way to ingrain a visceral feeling of inequality? What man, upon seeing this most basic weakness, not even on the job or under fire, could ever trust that his female counterpart was capable of being there when it counted?
And how could anyone fault him for this belief?

THIS is what capable women have been fighting against.

While it is laudable that that Captain Griest and Lieutenant Haver completed Ranger School and were awarded their Ranger tab, they are not Rangers. They are Ranger-qualified. Rangers are members of the 75th Ranger Regiment, and must participate in and successfully complete the Ranger Assessment and Selection Program. Additionally, before RASP, candidates must attend Airborne School and be Airborne qualified before being accepted and in RASP. Only after the two phases of RASP are completed, the candidate is awarded the 75th Ranger scroll patch. Then there is a 6 month probationary period as part of the Regiment, not to mention the much more difficult and strenuous training regimen of active regimental training. Do not belittle the status of elite warriors by labeling these two soldiers as Rangers. They've only taken the first steps on that journey. Rangers Lead the Way!

Well, I would suggest that there is an argument to be made about that, Sir.  I served in combat infantry units during my ten year career including the 82nd.  After graduating first in my class at RIP, then graduating Ranger School I went on to win my Division's Best Ranger competition and then competed in the Best Ranger competition in Benning.   For you to suggest that my tab or that of my fellow soldiers that served with me in the 82nd could not be called Rangers because we did not serve in Regiment is insulting and it's also not true.  A Ranger is about having the tab, living the code, not having the scroll.  Contrary to your belief.

FINALLY.
It's amazing how long we had to beg for the chance to simply prove what we've always known. (And if you never knew it, you're probably STILL too intractable to admit it -- right up until one of these women saves a mission and another soldier, which darn well might be your child. Perhaps then...)

STAND UP ALL, AND BE PROUD THAT THESE RANGERS ARE OURS.

HOOUP, CPT GRIEST & LT HAVER... ALL THE WAY!
(Backwards, in high heels, carrying extra baggage -- NO PROBLEM)

So, Mary, how many of those 7 million people do you wish to execute?   "Human vermin" is a phrase popular in high circles in Germany 75 years ago.   Perhaps killing millions would not be necessary.  If we return to the practices of the 18th century, hanging the same proportion of the population that was hanged in America in those days, we would only have to kill ten or twenty thousand people a year, year in and year out, year after year.   One problem with that is, on a per capita basis, we would outstrip ISIS, Iran, North Korea, etc. and that might not sit well will the rest of the world where we are still regarded as a civilized nation.  Though you are correct, those executed would be mostly men; we'd only have to hang a couple thousand women a year.

"I think that if you support the death penalty and an innocent man or woman is put to death that you share a moral culpability for that death"

What about imprisonment? If an innocent man spends 15 years in prison before being found innocentt then is everyone who supports imprisonment morally culpable?

What if a student did badly in an exam because his neighbor was playing the radio loud the previous night. Is the professor who gave him a B morally culpable? Are ALL of us who support grades morally culpable?

What about Snowden? He is hiding in the Ecuadorian embassy. Suppose he is innocent (he has not been tried). Are the Swedes culpable? Is Obama?

Life is not 100% fair and if we ban every practice which is even 1% unfair then we will bring civilization to an end.

I am in favor of a federal court overseeing every death sentence to make sure the evidence is watertight. But I suspect that the liberals will win their battle to make execution illegal just as they have won their battle to make abortion legal.
Good for you and good for the author of this op-ed. Everyone has their own path to follow in life and I'm glad that both of you are happy now.

As a graduate of the Ringling Bros., Barnum and Bailey Clown College, Class of 1982, and currently practicing law for the last two decades, I know better than most the two-sides of the coin.

Criminal defense is a blast. And the way I do it, I never leave my "clown" at home. Prosecutors hate me when we have a jury trial. I've learned the balance between just enough schmaltz to keep a jury interested, and too much "funnin'" where no one takes you seriously.

Finally, I find that those who never did anything before going to law school, usually become disenchanted with the practice of law at, about, the age of 30. However, those who did various things before law school, usually find longevity and satisfaction practicing law.

These are just my observations, there is nothing scientific about it. But I have found it to be true.

Regards
Leland Stanford Junior University.

The comments herein make me realize how incredibly good it would be to have an economic base of health care and education available to every citizen so we all could pursue "satisfying" work whether it lead to riches or plain contentment. We need a combination of high flying lawyers, acrobats, water carriers and, yes, clowns in the wonderful circus that life can be.

Why doesnt the fact that the legislature decided to end the penalty at some point settle the matter?

Why does the judiciary get to second guess the people's representatives?

I'm always curious as to what you think you mean by "declare unconstitutional"

Do you actually mean it "is" unconstitutional, in that it was not allowed by the Constitution at the time of draft [which is, it seems, simply false] or, is what you really mean something like the following:

"As I see it, the death penalty is immoral, therefore, it would be correect for a court to rule it unconstitutional"?

Because that to me isn't really legal analysis - it's simply legislating.

The Constitution did not and does not make the death penalty forbidden practice.

I'm as against the death penalty as anyone commenting here - but I think it incredibly dishonest to pretend that Ms. Greenhouse does anything other than substituting *her* moral worldview for a fair analysis of the meaning of the language employed in the Constitution, not simply at drafting, but by a reasonable and honest interpretation of the text.

What is "reasonable" may change over time, perceptions change, surely - but the notion that the constitution we have removed the power of government to execute people for crimes is simply false.

A better approach, from the standpoint of democracy, if the Left truly cares, would be a Constitutional amendment, not this silly rhetorical legerdemain to change the Constitution to suit your worldview

"Thou shalt not Kill" is equally cherry picking.
Do you believe soldiers in wars should not kill enemy soldiers?
Do you believe there is no such thing as a "justifiable" homicide?

To experience one's capabilities and talents fully engaged in work that benefits the self and others is one definition of achieved harmony in life. All work that contributes positively is worthy.

We, especially in America, are told we must aspire, which generally means making more money and having higher positions than those around us or those around whom we grew up. We should instead to do something worthy and search for expansive opportunities along the way, knowing that if they don't come, or don't provide the opportunity for service for which we had hoped, we will have led a productive, useful life nonetheless.

Twelve death penalty sentences out of 130, and 1 execution in 55 years seems hardly capacious, and there was nothing in the article that suggested any bias. The reality is juries think long and hard before they render a death penalty judgment and it is for the most heinous crimes and there are decades of review before the imposition of a penalty. Neither the legal or rational logic to claim the death penalty is unconstitutional supported by anything Ms Greenhouse reported from this judgment.

You may be opposed to the death penalty on many grounds, but there is nothing to suggest it is unconstitutional.
Let 'em make that catch without the stickum gloves. For all of the slack that Jerry Rice got, these guys today have a far more advantage with the gloves that they're allowed to wear.

I love people who claim to speak for the "framers,"  a group of men whom we all know thought about these issues in identical ways.  Clearly these people are a privileged few who have a special channel that allows them to commune with the "framers," and then dictate the convictions of the "framers" to us.  Whatever would we do without them? Think for ourselves, perhaps?

Great player. Great catch.

The gloves had a lot to do with it.
